trait.name: Earth Glide
entries: The elemental can burrow through nonmagical, unworked earth and stone. While doing so, the elemental doesn't disturb the material it moves through.

trait.name: Siege Monster
entries: The elemental deals double damage to objects and structures.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The elemental makes three slam attacks.

action.name: Slam
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}15 ({@damage 2d8 + 7}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Throw Stone
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 8} to hit, range 40 ft., one target. {@h}26 ({@damage 6d8 + 7}) bludgeoning damage.

reaction.name: Shield of the Ancients
entries: As a reaction, the elemental can bring up a rock shield from the ground giving it full cover and +5 AC until the end of the current turn.

fluff.name: Earth Elemental

entries: An earth elemental plods forward like a walking hill, club-like arms of jagged stone swinging at its sides. Its head and body consist of dirt and stone, occasionally set with chunks of metal, gems, and bright minerals.

Earth elementals glide through rock and earth as though they were liquid. Earthbound creatures have much to fear from an earth elemental, since the elemental can pinpoint the precise location of any foe that stands on solid ground in its vicinity.

Elementals are incarnations of the elements that make up the universe: air, earth, fire, and water. Though little more than animated energy on their own planes of existence, they can be called on by spellcasters and powerful beings to take shape and perform tasks.

entries.name: Living Elements
entries: On its home plane, an elemental is a bodiless life force. Its dim consciousness manifests as a physical shape only when focused by the power of magic. A wild spirit of elemental force has no desire except to course through the element of its native plane. Like beasts of the Material Plane, these elemental spirits have no society or culture, and little sense of being.

entries.name: Conjured by Magic
entries: Certain spells and magic items can conjure an elemental, summoning it from the Inner Planes to the Material Plane. Elementals instinctively resent being pulled from their native planes and bound into service. A creature that summons an elemental must assert force of will to control it.

entries.name: Bound and Shaped
entries: Powerful magic can bind an elemental spirit into a material template that defines a specific use and function. Invisible stalkers are air elementals bound to a specific form, in the same way that water elementals can be shaped into water weirds.

entries.name: Elemental Nature
entries: An elemental doesn't require air, food, drink, or sleep.

monster.name: Angrboda

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: Angrboda is a 30th level spellcaster capable of casting 9th level spells using her intelligence. She has the following spells prepared. +15 to hit, spell save {@dc 23}.

trait.name: Regeneration
entries: The giant regains 40 hit points at the start of its turn. If the giant takes acid or necrotic damage, this trait doesn't function at the start of its next turn. The giant dies only if it starts its turn with 0 hit points and doesn't regenerate.

trait.name: Angrboda's Rage (Recharges after a Short or Long Rest)
entries: As a bonus action, the giant can enter a rage at the start of its turn. The rage lasts for 1 minute. While raging, the giant gains the following benefits:
- The giant has advantage on Strength checks and Strength saving throws
- When it makes a melee weapon attack, the giant gains a +4 bonus to the damage roll.
- The giant has resistance to bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: Angrboda makes four attacks with its staff.

action.name: Staff of Deadly Monsters
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 18} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}30 ({@damage 3d12 + 9}) bludgeoning damage, or 34 ({@damage 3d12 + 11}) bludgeoning damage while raging.

action.name: Rock
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 18} to hit, range 60/240 ft., one target. {@h}31 ({@damage 4d10 + 9}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Cast a Spell
entries: Angrboda casts a known spell.

legendaryHeader: Angrboda can take 5 legendary actions, choosing from the options below. Only one legendary action can be used at a time and only at the end of another creature's turn. Angroboda regains spent legendary actions at the start of its turn.

legendary.name: Cast a Spell of Level 2 or Lower (Costs two actions)
entries: Angrboda can cast a spell that she knows that is of level two or lower.

legendary.name: Staff Attack
entries: Angrboda makes an attack with her staff.

legendary.name: Move (Costs two actions)
entries: Angrboda can up to her movement speed without provoking attacks of opportunity.

mythicHeader: Angrboda makes an attack with her staff.

entries: Angrboda is a wife of Loki and mother to Fenrir, Jormungdr, and Hel. Her children were taken from her by Odin due to a prophecy that Loki's children would doom Asgard. She seeks to reclaim her family to make it whole once more.

entries.name: Witch of the Woods
entries: Angrboda is a powerful arcane caster capable of casting 9th level spells. She has practiced her magic to protect her from the Aesir, other giants, and to give her the power to free her children.

entries.name: Mother of Monsters
entries: Angrboda is the Mother of Monsters. She is capable of transforming into a wolf or other creatures to adventure unnoticed. She has given birth to many other wolves and monstrosities which wander the lands and answer to her call.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The sun elf's casts one of the following spells, requiring no material components and using Charisma as the spellcasting ability (spell save {@dc 18}):

trait.name: Discern Lie
entries: The sun elf discerns when a creature in earshot speaks a lie in a language the sun elf knows.

trait.name: Fey Ancestry
entries: The sun elf has advantage on saving throws against being {@condition charmed}, and magic can't put the sun elf to sleep.

trait.name: Sunlight Sensitivity
entries: While in darkness, the sun elf has disadvantage on attack rolls, as well as on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on sight.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The sun elf makes three Sun Blade attacks.

action.name: Sun Blade
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 10} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}8 ({@damage 1d10 + 5}) piercing damage plus 16 ({@damage 2d8}) radiant damage.

bonus.name: Sun Step
entries: While the sun elf is within direct sunlight, it can use it's bonus action to misty step if it is not under any conditions that would prevent the spellcasting.

variant.name: Summon Elemental (1/Day)
entries: The sun elf attempts to magically summon a {@creature Air Elemental Myrmidon}, with a {@chance 50|50 percent} chance of success. If the attempt fails, the sun elf takes 5 ({@damage 1d10}) psychic damage. Otherwise, the summoned elemental appears in an unoccupied space within 60 feet of its summoner, acts as an ally of its summoner, and can't summon other elementals. It remains for 10 minutes, until it or its summoner dies, or until its summoner dismisses it as an action.

Sun elves had a deep respect for magic, particularly of the high magic variety, and often concentrated their studies on its nature and use. Sun elves had an advantage in this over other races, even other elves, for as a collective group, sun elves had a greater wealth of lore than any other, a collection accumulated over millennia. With the proper training, sun elven mages might be capable of warding an entire city or changing the landscape of a small region overnight, although such power was often used hesitantly and with restraint; the destruction of Myth Drannor and other disasters reminding sun elves that, with great power, came the need to restrain one's self. As a result, sun elves, as much out of an urge to prevent magical disasters as out of possessive arrogance, were hesitant to use their abilities learned as mages outside of their domains.[10]

Although sun elves favored the arcane, they did not neglect the divine and most sun elves were deeply religious. This piety was often intertwined with nationalism, as sun elves firmly believed they were the chosen people of the Seldarine. As in most other things, sun elves left no detail incomplete and the sun elven ceremonies devoted to the Seldarine were often long and drawn-out. For other races, these rites might even seem dull, with sun elves neglecting any hint of joy or merriness, which they believed disrespectful to the gods, in their worship.[12]

Sun elves generally paid heed to all the Seldarine,[12] though some did not consider Angharradh to be amongst the Seldarine.[13] Most found Corellon Larethian most worthy of their veneration. To the common sun elf, Corellon reflected the best qualities of a leader — wisdom, generosity, and firm leadership. Priests of the god often had a high place in sun elven society, advising nobility and aiding the military. Another god who commonly drew sun elf attention was Labelas Enoreth, who sun elves saw as the leader and protector of their culture in particular, as well as the keeper of wisdom and knowledge that sun elves valued so highly.[12]

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The sun elf's spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 12}). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

trait.name: Fey Ancestry
entries: The sun elf has advantage on saving throws against being {@condition charmed}, and magic can't put the sun elf to sleep.

trait.name: Sunlight Sensitivity
entries: While in sunlight, the sun elf has advantage on attack rolls, as well as on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on sight.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The sun elf makes two shortsword attacks.

action.name: Shortsword
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d6 + 4}) piercing damage plus 10 ({@damage 3d6}) poison damage.

action.name: Hand Crossbow
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 7} to hit, range 30/120 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d6 + 4}) piercing damage.

reaction.name: Parry
entries: The sun elf adds 3 to its AC against one melee attack that would hit it. To do so, the sun elf must see the attacker and be wielding a melee weapon.

variant.name: Sun Elf Magic Armor and Weapons

entries: Sun Elves often wear magic armor and carry magic weapons.
A sun elf warrior wearing {@item +2 Studded Leather Armor||+2 studded leather} and carrying a {@item +2 shortsword} has AC 20 and a +2 bonus on attack and damage rolls with shortsword attacks.

items.name: Special Equipment
entries: The drow wears {@item drow +2 studded leather armor|mm|+2 studded leather armor} and carries a {@item drow +2 shortsword|mm|+2 shortsword}. These items lose their enhancement bonuses permanently if they are exposed to sunlight for 1 hour or longer.

items.name: +2 Shortsword
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 9} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}9 ({@damage 1d6 + 6}) piercing damage plus 10 ({@damage 3d6}) poison damage.

from: {@item drow +2 studded leather armor|mm|+2 studded leather armor}

monster.name: Armed Draugr
languages: understands all languages it spoke in life but can't speak

trait.name: Undead Fortitude
entries: If damage reduces the draugr to 0 hit points, it must make a Constitution saving throw with a DC of 5 + the damage taken, unless the damage is radiant or from a critical hit. On a success, the draugr drops to 1 hit point instead.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The Draugr makes two weapon attacks.

action.name: Spear
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}12 ({@damage 1d8 + 8}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: War axe
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}8 ({@damage 1d8 + 4}) slashing damage.

action.name: Short Bow
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 1} to hit, range 60/120 ft., one target. {@h}2 ({@damage 1d6 â€’1}) piercing damage.

action.name: Longsword
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 6} to hit, range 60/120 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d8 +4}) piercing damage, or 8 ({@damage 1d10 +4}) piercing damage if used with both hands.

reaction.name: Parry
entries: The Draugr can use its reaction to parry an attack made against it. It's AC increases by 3 until the end of the current turn.

From somewhere in the darkness, a gurgling moan is heard. A form lurches into view, dragging one foot as it raises bloated arms and broken hands. The zombie advances, driven to kill anyone too slow to escape its grasp.

entries.name: Dark Servants
entries: Sinister necromantic magic infuses the remains of the dead, causing them to rise as zombies that do their creator's bidding without fear or hesitation. They move with a jerky, uneven gait, clad in the moldering apparel they wore when put to rest, and carrying the stench of decay.

Most zombies are made from humanoid remains, though the flesh and bones of any formerly living creature can be imbued with a semblance of life. Necromantic magic, usually from spells, animates a zombie. Some zombies rise spontaneously when dark magic saturates an area. Once turned into a zombie, a creature can't be restored to life except by powerful magic, such as a {@spell resurrection} spell.

A zombie retains no vestiges of its former self, its mind devoid of thought and imagination. A zombie left without orders simply stands in place and rots unless something comes along that it can kill. The magic animating a zombie imbues it with evil, so left without purpose, it attacks any living creature it encounters.

entries.name: Hideous Forms
entries: Zombies appear as they did in life, showing the wounds that killed them. However, the magic that creates these vile creatures often takes time to run its course. Dead warriors might rise from a battlefield, eviscerated and bloated after days in the sun. The muddy cadaver of a peasant could claw its way from the ground, riddled with maggots and worms. A zombie might wash ashore or rise from a marsh, swollen and reeking after weeks in the water.

entries.name: Mindless Soldiers
entries: Zombies take the most direct route to any foe, unable to comprehend obstacles, tactics, or dangerous terrain. A zombie might stumble into a fast-flowing river to reach foes on a far shore, clawing at the surface as it is battered against rocks and destroyed. To reach a foe below it, a zombie might step out of an open window. Zombies stumble through roaring infernos, into pools of acid, and across fields littered with caltrops without hesitation.

A zombie can follow simple orders and distinguish friends from foes, but its ability to reason is limited to shambling in whatever direction it is pointed, pummeling any enemy in its path. A zombie armed with a weapon uses it, but the zombie won't retrieve a dropped weapon or other tool until told to do so.

entries.name: Undead Nature
entries: A zombie doesn't require air, food, drink, or sleep.

trait.name: Regeneration
entries: The Child of Angrboda regenerates 15 hp at the start of its turn. If the Child of Angrboda takes psychic damage this trait does not function at the start of its next turn. The Child of Angrboda only dies if it starts its turn with 0 hp and doesn't regenerate.

trait.name: Keen Smell
entries: The Child of Angrboda has advantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on smell.

trait.name: Grappler
entries: The Child of Angrboda has advantage to attack {@condition grappled} creatures.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The Child of Angrboda uses its Frightful Presence and makes 7 attacks, 6 with its Claws, and 1 with its Bite.

action.name: Claws
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 13} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}14 ({@damage 2d6 + 7}) slashing damage.
On a hit, the Child of Angrboda can choose to grapple the creature instead.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 13} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}18 ({@damage 2d10 + 7}) piercing damage.

action.name: Frightful Presence
entries: Each creature of the Child of Angrboda's choice that is within 30 feet of the it and is aware of it must succeed on a {@dc 16} Wisdom saving throw or become {@condition frightened} for 1 minute. A creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success. If a creature's saving throw is successful or the effect ends for it, the creature is immune to the Child of Angrboda's Frightful Presence for the next 24 hours.

bonus.name: Aura of Poison
entries: The Child of Angrboda activates or deactivates this deathly aura. While active, the aura deals 5 poison damage to any creature that ends its turn within 30 feet of the Child of Angrboda. Any creature affected must make a {@dc 14} constitution saving throw or suffer the {@condition poisoned} condition until the end of their next turn.
The Child of Angrboda is a fearsome creature who hunts down prey for its mother.

trait.name: Spider Climb
entries: The spider can climb difficult surfaces, including upside down on ceilings, without needing to make an ability check.

trait.name: Web Sense
entries: While in contact with a web, the spider knows the exact location of any other creature in contact with the same web.

trait.name: Web Walker
entries: The spider ignores movement restrictions caused by webbing.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The spider makes one bite attack and two slam attacks.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d8 + 3}) piercing damage, and the target must make a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw, taking 19 ({@damage 4d8}) poison damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. If the poison damage reduces the target to 0 hit points, the target is stable but {@condition poisoned} for 1 hour, even after regaining hit points, and is {@condition paralyzed} while {@condition poisoned} in this way.
A Creature bitten by the spider is automatically {@condition grappled} and the spider cannot use its bite against another creature until it releases the creature or the creature breaks free.

action.name: Web {@recharge 5}
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 9} to hit, range 30/60 ft., one creature. {@h}The target is {@condition restrained} by webbing. As an action, the {@condition restrained} target can make a {@dc 15} Strength check, bursting the webbing on a success. The webbing can also be attacked and destroyed (AC 10; hp 5; vulnerability to fire damage; immunity to bludgeoning, poison, and psychic damage).

action.name: Slam
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d6 + 3}) bludgeoning damage.

To snare its prey, a giant spider spins elaborate webs or shoots sticky strands of webbing from its abdomen. Giant spiders are most commonly found underground, making their lairs on ceilings or in dark, web-filled crevices. Such lairs are often festooned with web cocoons holding past victims.

monster.name: Draugr
languages: understands all languages it spoke in life but can't speak

trait.name: Undead Fortitude
entries: If damage reduces the draugr to 0 hit points, it must make a Constitution saving throw with a DC of 5 + the damage taken, unless the damage is radiant or from a critical hit. On a success, the draugr drops to 1 hit point instead.

action.name: Slam
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}11 ({@damage 1d6 + 8}) bludgeoning damage.

A zombie armed with a weapon uses it, but the zombie won't retrieve a dropped weapon or other tool until told to do so.

entries.name: Undead Nature
entries: A zombie doesn't require air, food, drink, or sleep.

monster.name: Exploding Draugr
languages: understands all languages it spoke in life but can't speak

trait.name: Undead Fortitude
entries: If damage reduces the draugr to 0 hit points, it must make a Constitution saving throw with a DC of 5 + the damage taken, unless the damage is radiant or from a critical hit. On a success, the draugr drops to 1 hit point instead.

trait.name: Explosion On Death
entries: Upon dying, the Draugr explodes is a 10 ft radius. Each creature must make a {@dc 13} Dexterity saving throw or take ({@damage 4d6}) fire damage, half on a success.

action.name: Slam
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}11 ({@damage 1d6 + 8}) bludgeoning damage.

From somewhere in the darkness, a gurgling moan is heard. A form lurches into view, dragging one foot as it raises bloated arms and broken hands. The zombie advances, driven to kill anyone too slow to escape its grasp.

A zombie left without orders simply stands in place and rots unless something comes along that it can kill. The magic animating a zombie imbues it with evil, so left without purpose, it attacks any living creature it encounters.

A zombie might wash ashore or rise from a marsh, swollen and reeking after weeks in the water.

entries: Zombies take the most direct route to any foe, unable to comprehend obstacles, tactics, or dangerous terrain. A zombie might stumble into a fast-flowing river to reach foes on a far shore, clawing at the surface as it is battered against rocks and destroyed. To reach a foe below it, a zombie might step out of an open window. Zombies stumble through roaring infernos, into pools of acid, and across fields littered with caltrops without hesitation.

A zombie can follow simple orders and distinguish friends from foes, but its ability to reason is limited to shambling in whatever direction it is pointed, pummeling any enemy in its path. A zombie armed with a weapon uses it, but the zombie won't retrieve a dropped weapon or other tool until told to do so.

entries.name: Undead Nature
entries: A zombie doesn't require air, food, drink, or sleep.

immune.note: from nonmagical attacks that aren't silvered

trait.name: Shapechanger
entries: The Fenrir Werewolf can use its action to polymorph into a wolf-humanoid hybrid or into a wolf, or back into a humanoid. Its statistics, other than its AC, are the same in each form. Any equipment it is wearing or carrying isn't transformed. It reverts to its hybrid form if it dies.

trait.name: Keen Hearing and Smell
entries: The Fenrir werewolf has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on hearing or smell.

trait.name: Feel for the ground
entries: The Fenrir werewolf has {@sense tremorsense|MM} out to 30ft.

trait.name: Night Stalker
entries: The Fenrir werewolf has darkvision out to 120ft, and expertise in dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) checks to remain hidden.

trait.name: Regeneration
entries: The Fenrir werewolf regenerates 20hp at the start of its turn unless hit by a silver weapon.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The Fenrir werewolf has advantage on all saving throws against magic.

action.name: Multiattack (Wolf or Hybrid Form Only)
entries: The werewolf makes four attacks: one with its bite and three with its claws.

action.name: Bite (Wolf or Hybrid Form Only)
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 14} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}24 ({@damage 4d10 + 8}) piercing damage. If the target is a humanoid, it must succeed on a {@dc 16} Constitution saving throw or be cursed with Fenrir werewolf lycanthropy.

action.name: Claws (Wolf Hybrid Form Only)
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 14} to hit, reach 10 ft., one creature. {@h}10 ({@damage 2d6 + 8}) slashing damage.

action.name: Spear (Humanoid Form Only)
entries: {@atk mw,rw} {@hit 14} to hit, reach 5 ft. or range 20/60 ft., one creature. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d6 + 8}) piercing damage, or 9 ({@damage 1d8 + 8}) piercing damage if used with two hands to make a melee attack.

action.name: Multiattack (Humanoid Form Only)
entries: The Fenrir werewolf makes three spear attacks.

bonus.name: Transform
entries: The Fenrir werewolf can transform into a Humanoid, Hybrid, or Wolf form.

reaction.name: Evasion
entries: The Fenrir werewolf can use its reaction to succeed on a dexterity saving throw, taking no damage.

legendary.name: Slash (Hybrid or Wolf Form Only)
entries: The Fenrir werewolf makes one Claw attack.

legendary.name: Move
entries: The Fenrir werewolf moves up to half its movement speed without provoking attacks of opportunity.

legendary.name: Howl (Cost 2 actions)
entries: The Fenrir werewolf howls loudly. All creatures within 120ft of the werewolf must make a {@dc 18} Wisdom saving throw or be {@condition frightened} of the werewolf. A creature who succeeds on its saving throw is immune to that werewolf's howl for 24 hours. A creature that failed its saving throw can make a new one at the start of each of its turn.

variant.name: Nonhuman Lycanthropes
entries: The statistics presented in this section assume a base creature of human. However, you can also use the statistics to represent nonhuman lycanthropes, adding verisimilitude by allowing a nonhuman lycanthrope to retain one or more of its humanoid racial traits. For example, an elf werewolf might have the Fey Ancestry trait.

A werewolf is a savage predator. In its humanoid form, a werewolf has heightened senses, a fiery temper, and a tendency to eat rare meat. Its wolf form is a fearsome predator, but its hybrid form is more terrifying by far-a furred and well-muscled humanoid body topped by a ravening wolf's head. A werewolf can wield weapons in hybrid form, though it prefers to tear foes apart with its powerful claws and bite.

Most werewolves flee civilized lands not long after becoming afflicted. Those that reject the curse fear what will happen if they remain among their friends and family. Those that embrace the curse fear discovery and the consequences of their murderous acts. In the wild, werewolves form packs that also include wolves and dire wolves.

entries.name: Lycanthropes
entries: One of the most ancient and feared of all curses, lycanthropy can transform the most civilized humanoid into a ravening beast. In its natural humanoid form, a creature cursed by lycanthropy appears as its normal self. Over time, however, many lycanthropes acquire features suggestive of their animal form. In that animal form, a lycanthrope resembles a powerful version of a normal animal. On close inspection, its eyes show a faint spark of unnatural intelligence and might glow red in the dark.

Evil lycanthropes hide among normal folk, emerging in animal form at night to spread terror and bloodshed, especially under a full moon. Good lycanthropes are reclusive and uncomfortable around other civilized creatures, often living alone in wilderness areas far from villages and towns.

entries.name: Curse of Lycanthropy
entries: A humanoid creature can be afflicted with the curse of lycanthropy after being wounded by a lycanthrope, or if one or both of its parents are lycanthropes. A {@spell remove curse} spell can rid an afflicted lycanthrope of the curse, but a natural born lycanthrope can be freed of the curse only with a wish.

A lycanthrope can either resist its curse or embrace it. By resisting the curse, a lycanthrope retains its normal alignment and personality while in humanoid form. It lives its life as it always has, burying deep the bestial urges raging inside it. However, when the full moon rises, the curse becomes too strong to resist, transforming the individual into its beast form-or into a horrible hybrid form that combines animal and humanoid traits. When the moon wanes, the beast within can be controlled once again. Especially if the cursed creature is unaware of its condition, it might not remember the events of its transformation, though those memories often haunt a lycanthrope as bloody dreams.

Some individuals see little point in fighting the curse and accept what they are. With time and experience, they learn to master their shapechanging ability and can assume beast form or hybrid form at will. Most lycanthropes that embrace their bestial natures succumb to bloodlust, becoming evil, opportunistic creatures that prey on the weak.

entries.name: Player Characters as Lycanthropes
entries: A character who becomes a lycanthrope retains his or her statistics except as specified by lycanthrope type. The character gains the lycanthrope's speeds in non-humanoid form, damage immunities, traits, and actions that don't involve equipment. The character is proficient with the lycanthrope's natural attacks, such as its bite or claws, which deal damage as shown in the lycanthrope's statistics. The character can't speak while in animal form.

A non-lycanthrope humanoid hit by an attack that carries the curse of lycanthropy must succeed on a Constitution saving throw (DC 8 + the lycanthrope's proficiency bonus + the lycanthrope's Constitution modifier) or be cursed. If the character embraces the curse, his or her alignment becomes the one defined for the lycanthrope. The DM is free to decide that a change in alignment places the character under DM control until the curse of lycanthropy is removed.
The following information applies to specific lycanthropes.

entries.name: {@creature Werebear}
entries: The character gains a Strength of 19 if his or her score isn't already higher, and a +1 bonus to AC while in bear or hybrid form (from natural armor). Attack and damage rolls for the natural weapons are based on Strength.

entries.name: {@creature Wereboar}
entries: The character gains a Strength of 17 if his or her score isn't already higher, and a +1 bonus to AC while in boar or hybrid form (from natural armor). Attack and damage rolls for the tusks are based on Strength. For the Charge trait, the DC is 8 + the character's proficiency bonus + Strength modifier.

entries.name: {@creature Wererat}
entries: The character gains a Dexterity of 15 if his or her score isn't already higher. Attack and damage rolls for the bite are based on whichever is higher of the character's Strength and Dexterity.

entries.name: {@creature Weretiger}
entries: The character gains a Strength of 17 if his or her score isn't already higher. Attack and damage rolls for the natural weapons are based on Strength. For the Pounce trait, the DC is 8 + the character's proficiency bonus + Strength modifier.

entries.name: {@creature Werewolf}
entries: The character gains a Strength of 15 if his or her score isn't already higher, and a +1 bonus to AC while in wolf or hybrid form (from natural armor). Attack and damage rolls for the natural weapons are based on Strength.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The fey's innate spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 19}). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material or verbal components:

trait.name: Fey Step {@recharge 3}
entries: As a bonus action, the fey can teleport up to 120 feet to an unoccupied space it can see that contains water.

trait.name: Joyful Presence
entries: Any non-fey creature that starts its turn within 60 feet of the fey must make a {@dc 19} Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, the creature is {@condition charmed} for 1 minute. On a successful save, the creature becomes immune to any fey's Joyful Presence for 24 hours.
Whenever the fey deals damage to the {@condition charmed} creature, it can repeat the saving throw, ending the effect on itself on a success.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The fey has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Natural Camouflage
entries: While the fey is in at least 5 cubic feet of water it can use an action to become {@condition invisible}.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The fey makes two weapon attacks. The fey can cast one spell in place of one of these attacks.

action.name: Rapier
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 9} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d8 + 4}) slashing damage plus 4 ({@damage 1d8}) psychic damage.

action.name: Longbow
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 9} to hit, range 150/600 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d8 + 4}) piercing damage plus 4 ({@damage 1d8}) psychic damage.

reaction.name: Magic to my Music
entries: The fey can use its reaction to play a short tune on its fiddle to cast the spell {@spell counterspell} at 4th level.
To be not just ruled by emotions, but physically changed by them? Better to have no emotions at all.

entries.name: Fossergrimm
entries: Fossergrimm dwell in the verdant splendor of the Feywild. They choose isolated areas that contain water features, such as a small lake, pond, or waterfall. They are magically bound these areas only free to leave to find a mate before returning.

Their songs were known to lure women and children to lakes or streams where they would drown. However, not all of these spirits were necessarily malevolent; in fact, many stories exist that indicate at the very least that nÃ¸kken were entirely harmless to their audience and attracted not only women and children, but men as well with their sweet songs. Stories also exist where in the Fossegrim agreed to live with a human who had fallen in love with him, but many of these stories ended with the nÃ¸kken returning to his home, usually a nearby waterfall or brook.

entries.name: Magically Bound
entries: Being bound to their waterfall, fossergrim were unable to go more than 1,000ft (300m) from them; doing so resulted in them falling ill and dying within 24 hours. Whenever a fossergrim's waterfall froze during the winter they entered a deep torpor. However, they remained aware of their surroundings during this time and would awaken to protect the waterfall if necessary.

entries.name: Talented Musician
entries: The fossegrim is described as an exceptionally talented fiddler: the sounds of forest, wind and water play over his fiddle strings. They say the strÃ¶mkarl's ("river-man") song is said to have eleven variations, the final one being reserved for the night spirits because when it is played, "tables and benches, cup and can, gray-beards and grandmothers, blind and lame, even babes in the cradle" will begin to dance.

monster.name: Frost Draugr
languages: understands all languages it spoke in life but can't speak

trait.name: Undead Fortitude
entries: If damage reduces the draugr to 0 hit points, it must make a Constitution saving throw with a DC of 5 + the damage taken, unless the damage is radiant or from a critical hit. On a success, the draugr drops to 1 hit point instead.

trait.name: Freezing Sphere On Death
entries: Upon dying, the Draugr explodes is a 20 ft radius. Each creature must make a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw or take ({@damage 8d8}) cold damage and be {@condition paralyzed} for one minute, or take half damage on a success.
A {@condition paralyzed} creature can make another saving throw at the end of each of its turn to end the effect.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The Draugr makes two Unarmed Strikes.

action.name: Unarmed Strike
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}8 ({@damage 1d8 + 4}) bludgeoning damage, plus 3 ({@damage 1d6}) cold damage.

action.name: Freezing Orb
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 6} to hit, range 20/40 ft., one target. {@h}9 ({@damage 2d8}) cold damage.

From somewhere in the darkness, a gurgling moan is heard. A form lurches into view, dragging one foot as it raises bloated arms and broken hands. The zombie advances, driven to kill anyone too slow to escape its grasp.

entries.name: Dark Servants
entries: Sinister necromantic magic infuses the remains of the dead, causing them to rise as zombies that do their creator's bidding without fear or hesitation. They move with a jerky, uneven gait, clad in the moldering apparel they wore when put to rest, and carrying the stench of decay.

Most zombies are made from humanoid remains, though the flesh and bones of any formerly living creature can be imbued with a semblance of life. Necromantic magic, usually from spells, animates a zombie. Some zombies rise spontaneously when dark magic saturates an area. Once turned into a zombie, a creature can't be restored to life except by powerful magic, such as a {@spell resurrection} spell.

A zombie retains no vestiges of its former self, its mind devoid of thought and imagination. A zombie left without orders simply stands in place and rots unless something comes along that it can kill. The magic animating a zombie imbues it with evil, so left without purpose, it attacks any living creature it encounters.

entries.name: Hideous Forms
entries: Zombies appear as they did in life, showing the wounds that killed them. However, the magic that creates these vile creatures often takes time to run its course. Dead warriors might rise from a battlefield, eviscerated and bloated after days in the sun. The muddy cadaver of a peasant could claw its way from the ground, riddled with maggots and worms. A zombie might wash ashore or rise from a marsh, swollen and reeking after weeks in the water.

entries.name: Mindless Soldiers
entries: Zombies take the most direct route to any foe, unable to comprehend obstacles, tactics, or dangerous terrain. A zombie might stumble into a fast-flowing river to reach foes on a far shore, clawing at the surface as it is battered against rocks and destroyed. To reach a foe below it, a zombie might step out of an open window. Zombies stumble through roaring infernos, into pools of acid, and across fields littered with caltrops without hesitation.

A zombie can follow simple orders and distinguish friends from foes, but its ability to reason is limited to shambling in whatever direction it is pointed, pummeling any enemy in its path. A zombie armed with a weapon uses it, but the zombie won't retrieve a dropped weapon or other tool until told to do so.

entries.name: Undead Nature
entries: A zombie doesn't require air, food, drink, or sleep.

trait.name: Keen Sight
entries: The roc has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on sight.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The Roc makes three attacks: one with its beak and two with its talons.

action.name: Beak
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 14} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}33 ({@damage 5d8 + 11}) piercing damage.

action.name: Talons
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 14} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}28 ({@damage 5d6 + 11}) slashing damage, and the target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 20}). Until this grapple ends, the target is {@condition restrained}, and the roc can't use its talons on another target.

legendary.name: Beak
entries: The Roc can spend 1 Legendary action to make a beak attack.

legendary.name: Gust
entries: The Roc can spend two Legendary Actions to create a Gust of Wind.

The Roc flaps its wings creating a strong gust of wind. Each creature within 40 ft. of the Roc must make a {@dc 21} Strength Saving throw or be pushed back 20 feet and knocked {@condition prone}. On a success, a creature is pushed back 10 feet.

legendary.name: Drop
entries: The Roc can spend 1 Legendary Action to drop a creature it his currently grappling.

At first sight, a roc's silhouette looks much like any other bird of prey. As it descends, however, its unearthly size becomes terrifyingly clear. In flight, a roc's wingspan spreads two hundred feet or more. At rest, perched upon the mountain peaks that are its home, this monstrous bird rivals the oldest dragons in size.

entries.name: Sky Titans
entries: In the ancient days when giants battled dragons for control of the world, Annam, the father of the giant gods, created the rocs so that his worshipers might challenge the dragons' dominance of the air.
When the war ended, the rocs were freed from giant domination and spread throughout the world.

Though cloud giants and storm giants sometimes tame these great birds, rocs treat even giants as potential prey. They fly great distances in search of food, soaring high above the clouds to reach their favored hunting grounds. A roc seldom hunts swift or small creatures, and it ignores towns and forests where prey can easily take cover. When it locates a large and slow-moving target such as a giant, a whale, or an elephant, a roc dives down to snatch its prey in its massive talons.

entries.name: Remote and Alone
entries: Rocs are solitary creatures that can live for centuries. They lair in nests made from trees, tents, broken ships, and the remains of caravans they carry off, placing these massive tangles in mountain clefts out of the reach of lesser creatures.

Sometimes a roc's nest contains treasures from the caravans or ships they raid, but these creatures are heedless of such baubles. More rarely, a nest holds eggs that are taller than a human, produced by the rocs' infrequent mating.

trait.name: Fire Absorption
entries: Whenever the obsidian is subjected to fire damage, it takes no damage and instead regains a number of hit points equal to the fire damage dealt.

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (3/Day)
entries: If the obsidian fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.

action.name: Claws
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 19} to hit, reach 15 ft., one target. {@h}23 ({@damage 2d12 + 10}) slashing damage.

action.name: Tail
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 19} to hit, reach 30 ft., one target. {@h}23 ({@damage 3d8 + 10}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 19} to hit, reach 15 ft., one target. {@h}21 ({@damage 2d10 + 10}) piercing damage and {@damage 4d6} fire damage. A creature of Huge size or smaller bitten by Obsidian must make a {@dc 25} Athletics check or be {@condition grappled} and {@condition restrained} by Obsidian.

action.name: Frightful Presence
entries: Each creature of the dragon's choice that is aware of it must succeed on a {@dc 23} Wisdom saving throw or become {@condition frightened} for 1 minute. If a creature's saving throw is successful or the effect ends for it, the creature is immune to the dragon's Frightful Presence for the next 24 hours.

action.name: Swallow
entries: Obsidian swallows a creature {@condition grappled} in its mouth. While swallowed, the target is {@condition blinded} and {@condition restrained}, it has total cover against attacks and other effects outside the creature, and it takes 56 ({@damage 16d6}) fire damage at the start of each of the creature's turns.

action.name: Fire Breath {@recharge 5}
entries: The dragon exhales fire in a 120-foot cone. Each creature in that area must make a {@dc 26} Dexterity saving throw, taking 83 ({@damage 15d10}) fire damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

action.name: Psychic Breath {@recharge 5}
entries: Kinetic Breath The dragon exhales a beam of glimmering energy in a 120-foot line that is 15 feet wide. Each creature in that line must succeed on a {@dc 24} Wisdom saving throw or become {@condition restrained} until the start of its next turn. Obsidian may telekinetically hurl any creature or object {@condition restrained} in this way up to 120 feet in any direction, dealing {@damage 1d6} bludgeoning damage per 10 feet traveled.

legendary.name: Detect
entries: Obsidian makes a Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check.

legendary.name: Tail Attack
entries: Obsidian makes a tail attack.

legendary.name: Cast an At will Spell
entries: Obsidian casts an at-will Spell.

legendary.name: Wing Attack (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: Obsidian beats its wings. Each creature within 30 feet of the dragon must succeed on a {@dc 25} Dexterity saving throw or take 24 ({@damage 4d6 + 10}) bludgeoning damage and be knocked {@condition prone}. The dragon can then fly up to half its flying speed.

legendary.name: Lightning Storm (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: Obsidian uses Lightning Storm: the creature magically creates three bolts of lightning, each of which can strike a target the creature can see within 120 feet of it. A target must make a {@dc 25} Dexterity saving throw, taking 22 ({@damage 4d10}) lightning damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

Obsidian is the most terrifying dragons to exist. The offspring of a Red and an unknown Gem dragon, Obsidian is one of a kind. He prospered during the age of Giants and Dragons and was worshiped as God, with some Chromatic Dragons hoping he would usurp and replace Tiamat (Tahksis) at some point.

As his power grew, so did his ambition. He eventually began to challenge the Gods of the world, and fearful for their destruction, they tricked Obsidian into a deep slumber rather than risk their lives.

monster.name: Spellcasting Draugr
languages: understands all languages it spoke in life but can't speak

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The Draugr is a 7th-level spellcaster (spell save {@dc 14}, +6 to hit with spell attacks) that needs only verbal components to cast its spells. Its spellcasting ability is Wisdom, and it has the following spells prepared

trait.name: Undead Fortitude
entries: If damage reduces the draugr to 0 hit points, it must make a Constitution saving throw with a DC of 5 + the damage taken, unless the damage is radiant or from a critical hit. On a success, the draugr drops to 1 hit point instead.

From somewhere in the darkness, a gurgling moan is heard. A form lurches into view, dragging one foot as it raises bloated arms and broken hands. The zombie advances, driven to kill anyone too slow to escape its grasp.

entries.name: Dark Servants
entries: Sinister necromantic magic infuses the remains of the dead, causing them to rise as zombies that do their creator's bidding without fear or hesitation. They move with a jerky, uneven gait, clad in the moldering apparel they wore when put to rest, and carrying the stench of decay.

Most zombies are made from humanoid remains, though the flesh and bones of any formerly living creature can be imbued with a semblance of life. Necromantic magic, usually from spells, animates a zombie. Some zombies rise spontaneously when dark magic saturates an area. Once turned into a zombie, a creature can't be restored to life except by powerful magic, such as a {@spell resurrection} spell.

A zombie retains no vestiges of its former self, its mind devoid of thought and imagination. A zombie left without orders simply stands in place and rots unless something comes along that it can kill. The magic animating a zombie imbues it with evil, so left without purpose, it attacks any living creature it encounters.

entries.name: Hideous Forms
entries: Zombies appear as they did in life, showing the wounds that killed them. However, the magic that creates these vile creatures often takes time to run its course. Dead warriors might rise from a battlefield, eviscerated and bloated after days in the sun. The muddy cadaver of a peasant could claw its way from the ground, riddled with maggots and worms. A zombie might wash ashore or rise from a marsh, swollen and reeking after weeks in the water.

entries.name: Mindless Soldiers
entries: Zombies take the most direct route to any foe, unable to comprehend obstacles, tactics, or dangerous terrain. A zombie might stumble into a fast-flowing river to reach foes on a far shore, clawing at the surface as it is battered against rocks and destroyed. To reach a foe below it, a zombie might step out of an open window. Zombies stumble through roaring infernos, into pools of acid, and across fields littered with caltrops without hesitation.

A zombie can follow simple orders and distinguish friends from foes, but its ability to reason is limited to shambling in whatever direction it is pointed, pummeling any enemy in its path. A zombie armed with a weapon uses it, but the zombie won't retrieve a dropped weapon or other tool until told to do so.

entries.name: Undead Nature
entries: A zombie doesn't require air, food, drink, or sleep.

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (3/Day)
entries: If the leviathan fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.

trait.name: Partial Freeze
entries: If the leviathan takes 50 cold damage or more during a single turn, the leviathan partially freezes; until the end of its next turn, its speeds are reduced to 20 feet, and it makes attack rolls with disadvantage.

trait.name: Siege Monster
entries: The leviathan deals double damage to objects and structures.

trait.name: Air Form
entries: The leviathan can enter a hostile creature's space and stop there. It can move through a space as narrow as 1 inch wide without squeezing.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The leviathan makes two Thundering Strike attacks and one Gust attack.

action.name: Thundering Strike
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 15} to hit, reach 20 ft., one target. {@h}21 ({@damage 2d12 + 8}) thunder damage plus 13 ({@damage 2d12}) lightning damage.

action.name: Gust
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 15} to hit, reach 20 ft., one target. {@h}19 ({@damage 2d10 + 8}) thunder damage plus 10 ({@damage 3d6}) lightning damage.

action.name: Thunder Wave {@recharge}
entries: The storm leviathan magically creates a wave of stormy air that extends from a point it can see within 120 feet of itself. The wave is up to 250 feet long, up to 250 feet tall, and up to 50 feet wide. Each creature in the wave must make a {@dc 24} Strength saving throw. On a failed save, a creature takes 45 ({@damage 7d12}) thunder damage and is {@condition deafened}. On a successful save, a creature takes half as much damage and isn't {@condition deafened}. The storm spreads out across the area in all directions, extinguishing unprotected flames in its area and within 250 feet of it, and then it vanishes.

legendary.name: Move
entries: The storm leviathan moves up to its speed.

legendary.name: Thundering Strike
entries: The storm leviathan makes one Thundering Strike attack.

legendary.name: Suffocation, No breathing (Costs two actions)
entries: The Leviathan chooses one creature within 60ft of it. That creature must make a successful ({@dc 19}) constitution saving throw or begin suffocating. While suffocating, the creature is unable to speak verbally or cast spells that require a verbal component. At the end each of their turns they can make a new save to end the effect.
A storm leviathan is an immense creature that acts as a force of nature. When called forth, a leviathan arises from the sky and takes the form of a hurricane being ridden by a titan.

Usually found only on the Elemental Plane of Air, a leviathan sometimes travels through a portal to another world, where folk attempt to contain it. Nihilistic cults have also been known to perform arduous rituals to summon a leviathan to a world, with the aim of using the creature to destroy coastal communities. Those cultists often consider it a blessing to be blown apart by the elemental's thundering blasts.

monster.name: Valkonen

trait.name: Chromatic Awakening (Recharges after a Short or Long Rest)
entries: If the greatwyrm would be reduced to 0 hit points, its current hit point total instead resets to 525 hit points, it recharges its Breath Weapon, and it regains any expended uses of Legendary Resistance. Additionally, the greatwyrm can now use the options in the "Mythic Actions" section for 1 hour. Award a party an additional 105,000 XP (210,000 XP total) for defeating the greatwyrm after its Chromatic Awakening activates.

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (4/Day)
entries: If the greatwyrm fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.

trait.name: Unusual Nature
entries: Valkonen doesn't require food or drink.

trait.name: Arcane Master
entries: Valkonen doesn't need to use his action to activate a magical effect which has a duration and has already been cast.

trait.name: Master Shapechanger
entries: Valkonen can change their shape to that of any creature. Additionally, Valkonen can shapechange to that of a magical object as if it were the {@spell True Polymorph} though he remains sentient and can communicate telepathically to any creature within 120 feet of it. While in this form Valkonen maintains their true sight trait.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: Valkonen makes one Bite attack and two Claw attacks.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 19} to hit, reach 15 ft., one target. {@h}22 ({@damage 2d10 + 11}) piercing damage plus 13 ({@damage 2d12}) force damage.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 19} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}20 ({@damage 2d8 + 11}) slashing damage. If the target is a Huge or smaller creature, it is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 21}) and is {@condition restrained} until this grapple ends. Valkonen can have only one creature {@condition grappled} this way at a time.

action.name: Tail
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 19} to hit, reach 20 ft., one target. {@h}20 ({@damage 2d8 + 11}) bludgeoning damage. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 27} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}.

action.name: Breath Weapon {@recharge 5}
entries: Valkonen exhales a blast of energy in a 300-foot cone. Each creature in that area must make a {@dc 27} Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save, the creature takes 78 ({@damage 12d12}) cold damage. On a successful save, the creature takes half as much damage.

legendary.name: Attack
entries: Valkonen makes one Claw or Tail attack.

legendary.name: Wing Attack (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: Valkonen beats its wings. Each creature within 30 feet of it must succeed on a {@dc 26} Dexterity saving throw or take 17 ({@damage 2d6 + 10}) bludgeoning damage and be knocked {@condition prone}. The greatwyrm can then fly up to half its flying speed.

legendary.name: Dark Bolts (Costs 3 Actions)
entries: Valkonen creates four bolts of black lightning. All bolts hit a creature of Valkonen's choice it can see within 120 feet of it, dealing 28 ({@damage 4d8 + 12}) lightning damage and 28 ({@damage 4d8 + 12}) necrotic damage to its target, then disappears.

legendary.name: Move
entries: Valkonen can move up to its movement speed without provoking attacks of opportunity.

mythicHeader: If Valkonen's Chromatic Awakening trait has activated in the last hour, it can use the options below as legendary actions.

mythic.name: Bite
entries: Valkonen makes one Bite attack.

mythic.name: Chromatic Flare (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: Valkonen flares with elemental energy. Each creature in a 60-foot-radius sphere centered on the greatwyrm must succeed on a {@dc 26} Dexterity saving throw or take 22 ({@damage 5d8}) cold and 22 ({@damage 5d8}) necrotic damage.

mythic.name: Casts a spell (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: Valkonen can cast a spell he knows with the casting time of one action or bonus action.

variant.name: Customizing Dragons
entries: You can customize any dragon's stat block to reflect the dragon's unique character. Minor changes such as those below are easy to make and have no impact on a dragon's challenge rating.

entries.name: Languages
entries: Most dragons prefer to speak Draconic but learn Common for dealing with allies and minions. But given their high Intelligence and long life span, dragons can easily learn additional languages. You can add languages to a dragon's stat block.

entries.name: Skills
entries: Most dragons are proficient in the {@skill Perception} and {@skill Stealth} skills, and many dragons have additional skill proficiencies. As with languages, you can customize a dragon's skill list (even doubling their proficiency bonus with certain skills) to reflect particular interests and activities. You can also give a dragon tool proficiencies, particularly if the dragon spends time in Humanoid form.

entries.name: Spells
entries: {@note See the "Variant: Dragons as Innate Spellcasters" inset(s), below.}

entries.name: Other Traits and Actions
entries: You can borrow traits and actions from other monsters to add unique flavor to a dragon. Consider these examples:

items.name: Flyby
entries: The dragon is an agile flier, quick to fly out of enemies' reach.
The dragon doesn't provoke an opportunity attack when it flies out of an enemy's reach.

items.name: Mimicry
entries: Impersonating characters or their allies could be a fun trick for a crafty dragon.
The dragon can mimic any sounds it has heard, including voices. A creature that hears the sounds can tell they are imitations with a successful {@dc 16} Wisdom ({@skill Insight}) check.

items.name: Rejuvenation
entries: You might decide that dragons in your campaign, being an essential part of the Material Plane, are nearly impossible to destroy. A dragon's life essence might be preserved in the egg from which it first emerged, in its hoard, or in a cavernous hall at the center of the world, just as a lich's essence is hidden in a phylactery.

If it has an essence-preserving object, a destroyed dragon gains a new body in {@dice 1d10} days, regaining all its hit points and becoming active again. The new body appears within 5 feet of the object.

items.name: Special Senses
entries: Most dragons have {@sense blindsight} and {@sense darkvision}. You might upgrade {@sense blindsight} to {@sense truesight}, or you could give a dragon with a burrowing speed {@sense tremorsense|MM}.

items.name: Tunneler
entries: The dragon can burrow through solid rock at half its burrowing speed and leaves a tunnel in its wake.

The most ancient chromatic dragons, who have survived over twelve hundred years of mortal life and acquired vast hoards worth millions of gold pieces, can achieve a form of apotheosis, reaching a level of power approaching that of Tiamat's mighty aspect. The competitive avarice of dragonkind and the interference of adventurers prevent most dragons from attaining this level of power. But a chromatic dragon who can outwit all rivals and overcome all potential thieves can rise to become one of the mightiest of dragons.

Often a chromatic greatwyrm's ascension involves fusing the power of a single dragon's echoes across different worlds of the Material Plane. The black greatwyrm Chronepsis, for example, is said to have stalked multiple worlds and devoured many of his echoes before withdrawing to a planar lair in the Outlands. The red greatwyrm Ashardalon worked with a balor to ritually drain the power of his echoes, then infused their power into himself by implanting the balor where his heart had been.

In both size and power, chromatic greatwyrms exceed even ancient dragons. The energy of their breath weapons courses over their bodies and glows under their scales, and elemental forces rage around them when they exert their wrath. They no longer need to eat or drink, as their vast hoards magically sustain them. And their power can raze a city to the ground, destroying buildings and defenders alike.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The Valkyrie's spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 25}). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

trait.name: Angelic Weapons
entries: The Valkyrie's weapon attacks are magical. When the Valkyrie hits with any weapon, the weapon deals an extra {@dice 2d8} radiant damage (included in the attack).

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The Valkyrie has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The Valkyrie makes two spear attacks.

action.name: Spear
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 14} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}21 ({@damage 4d6 + 7}) slashing damage plus 9 ({@damage 2d8}) radiant damage.

action.name: Longbow
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 14} to hit, range 150/600 ft., one target. {@h}16 ({@damage 2d8 + 7}) piercing damage plus 9 ({@damage 2d8}) radiant damage.

action.name: Stomp
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 11} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}25 ({@damage 6d6 + 4}) bludgeoning damage.

legendary.name: Charge
entries: The Valkyrie charges to a hostile creature within 60 ft. of it without provoking opportunity attacks and makes one spear attack against the target.

legendary.name: Fury of Blades (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: The Valkyrie spews blades from its wings at a creature within range. The creature must make a {@dc 23} Dexterity saving throw, taking 14 ({@damage 4d6}) piercing damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

legendary.name: Righteous Stomp (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: The Valkyrie teleports to one creature within 30 ft. range that creature must make a {@dc 22} dexterity saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone} and then the Valkyrie makes 3 stomp attacks on a failed save.

mythic.name: Regenerate
entries: Once per day when the Valkyrie reaches 0 hit points it regains all lost hitpoints.

mythic.name: Fury Swipes (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: The Valkyrie spews blades from its wings in a 30 ft. range to each creature of its choice. Each creature must make a {@dc 19} Dexterity saving throw, taking 14 ({@damage 4d6}) piercing damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

mythic.name: Valkyrie's War Cry (Costs 3 Actions)
entries: Once per day after using its regenerate, the Valkyrie can cast the spell {@spell Psychic Scream|XGE}.

An angel is a celestial agent sent forth into the planes to further its god's agenda for weal or woe. Its sublime beauty and presence can drive awestruck onlookers to their knees. Yet angels are destroyers too, and their appearance portends doom as often as it signals hope.

entries.name: Shards of the Divine
entries: Angels are formed from the astral essence of benevolent gods and are thus divine beings of great power and foresight.

Angels act out the will of their gods with tireless devotion. Even chaotic good deities command lawful good angels, knowing that the angels' dedication to order best allows them to fulfill divine commands. An angel follows a single driving purpose, as decreed by its deity. However, an angel is incapable of following commands that stray from the path of law and good.

An angel slays evil creatures without remorse. As the embodiment of law and good, an angel is almost never mistaken in its judgments. This quality can create a sense of superiority in an angel, a sense that comes to the fore when an angel's task conflicts with the goals of another creature. The angel never acquiesces or gives way. When an angel is sent to aid mortals, it is sent not to serve but to command. The gods of good therefore send their angels among mortals only in response to the most dire circumstances.

entries.name: Fallen Angels
entries: An angel's moral compass grants it a sense of infallibility that can sometimes spell its undoing. Angels are usually too wise to fall for a simple deception, but sometimes pride can lead one to commit an evil act. Whether intentional or accidental, such an act is a permanent stain that marks the angel as an outcast. Fallen angels retain their power but lose their connection to the deities from which they were made. Most fallen angels take their banishment personally, rebelling against the powers they served by seeking rulership over a section of the Abyss or a place among other fallen in the hierarchy of the Nine Hells. Zariel, the ruler of the first layer of the Nine Hells, is such a creature. Rather than rebel, some fallen angels resign themselves to an isolated existence on the Material Plane, living in disguise as simple hermits. If they are redeemed, they can become powerful allies dedicated to justice and compassionate service.

entries.name: Immortal Nature
entries: An angel doesn't require food, drink, or sleep.

entries.name: Solar
entries: A solar is godlike in its glory and power.

On the battlefield, the solar's sword flies into the fray on its own, and a single arrow from a solar's bow can strike a target dead on contact. So great is a solar's celestial might that even demon princes shrink at its resonant commands.

It is said that only twenty-four solars exist. The few solars that are known are stewards of specific deities. The others rest in a state of contemplation, waiting for the time when their services are needed to stave off some cosmic threat to the cause of good.

monster.name: Warlock (Pact of the Blade)

resist.note: from nonmagical attacks that aren't silvered

languages: the languages it knew in life

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The deathlock casts one of the following spells, using Charisma as the spellcasting ability (spell save {@dc 22}):

trait.name: Devil's Sight
entries: Magical darkness doesn't impede the deathlock's {@sense darkvision}.

trait.name: Turn Resistance
entries: The deathlock has advantage on saving throws against any effect that turns Undead.

trait.name: Unusual Nature
entries: The deathlock doesn't require air, food, drink, or sleep.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The deathlock makes two ranged weapon attacks.

action.name: Pact Weapon Rifle
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 14} to hit, range 120/180 ft., one target. {@h}22 ({@damage 1d12 + 16}) piercing damage.

bonus.name: Quickstep
entries: The deathlock can take a dash action as a bonus action.

bonus.name: Give orders
entries: The deathlock can use a bonus action to inspire up to 3 friendly creatures within 30ft. to give them advantage on their next attack roll.

legendary.name: Cast a spell (cost 2 actions)
entries: The deathlock casts a known spell of its choice that has the casting time of 1 action or 1 bonus action.

legendary.name: Move
entries: The deathlock moves up to its speed without provoking opportunity attacks.

legendary.name: Shoot
entries: The deathlock makes 1 ranged weapon attack.

Though deathlocks exist to serve their patrons, they retain some freedom when it comes to devising tactics and carrying out plans. Powerful deathlocks recruit lesser creatures to help them carry out their missions, becoming the masterminds behind vast conspiracies and intrigues that culminate in the accomplishment of great acts of evil.

entries.name: Deathlocks
entries: The forging of a pact between a warlock and a patron is no minor occasion—at least not for the warlock. The consequences of breaking that pact can be dire and, in some cases, lethal. A warlock who fails to live up to a bargain with an evil patron runs the risk of rising from the dead as a deathlock, a foul Undead driven to serve its otherworldly patron.
An powerful necromancer might also discover the wicked methods of creating a deathlock and then subjugate it, acting as the deathlock's patron.
